titleproper.value: Guide to the New-York Historical Society Postcard Collection [graphic]<lb/>circa 1898-1965 (bulk, 1900-1950)<lb/> <num>PR 54</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Jennifer Lewis (2002) and Joseph Ditta (2018-2020).

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2020-01-07T15:37:30</date>

abstract.value: The New-York Historical Society Postcard Collection contains approximately 62,000 postcard views of the United States, New York State, New York City and international geographic locations, depicting, buildings, historical scenes, modes of transportation, tourist attractions, holiday greetings and other subjects. The collection is strongest for New York City.

p.value: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)

This collection, formerly called the Postcard File, should now be cited as the <emph render="bold">New-York Historical Society Postcard Collection, PR 054, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society</emph>.

The Albertype Company, begun in 1889 in Brooklyn, New York, produced photographic views, postcards, and souvenir booklets for areas across the United States. The company's output eventually reached several million pictures per year. The Albertype Company ceased operation shortly after the death of Herman L. Wittemann, the son of one of the founding Wittemann brothers, in 1952.

About 10,000 cards come from the stock file of the Brooklyn-based Albertype Company. Other major publishers represented in the collection include the American Souvenir Card Company, the Illustrated Postal Card Company, and the Detroit Publishing Company.

subject.value: Church buildings -- New York (State)  -- New York.

Series I. Geographic Locations | United States (except New York)21455421.39 Linear feet(in 39.5 boxes)circa 1898-1965 (bulk, 1900-1950)Arrangement

Cards are filed alphabetically by U.S. state and thereunder by city or geographical feature. Extensively represented cities are subdivided by building types, streets and other subjects.

New York City | Souvenir Folders & Sets21543096-DScope and Contents

General

Includes "Souvenir Folder of New York, The City of Wonders" (Manhattan Card Publishing Co.), the gift of Analee Wulfkuhle (accession no. PPAC.2018.024). Ms. Wulfkuhle's mother, Ella Jean Skidmore, traveled to New York City with her Topeka (Kansas) High School classmates in 1936, and marked with a check in the souvenir folder each sight she saw. Inserted in the folder is a postcard of the George Washington Bridge, postmarked 1933, and sent by Ella Jean to a Skidmore relative in Carbondale, Kansas.

Unusual Postcards21542295Scope and Contents

Includes cards on leather, cards on birch bark, a card on a cross section of a tree, embroidered cards and cards on fabric (one with a portrait of Miss Edith Cavell), cat cards (with one that squeaks when squeezed), cards with feathers, cards that are drink coasters, embossed cards of New York City and State scenes, accordion-folder cards that pull open, and a lenticular print card (when tilted it displays alternate images of Theodore Roosevelt and the White House).
